Award.AwardTitle: Building Sustainable Pathways to STEM Teaching

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
With Capacity Building funds from the NSF Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, the University of Hawaii Manoa (UHM), in conjunction with faculty across colleges in the UH System and with outside experts, will establish and strengthen the infrastructure and collaborations that will ultimately lead to increasing the number and diversity of highly-qualified mathematics and science teachers in high-need schools across Hawaii. In Hawaii, the attrition rate for licensed teachers who come from out of state or who start teaching prior to completion of a teacher preparation program is significantly higher (50%) than for those who complete teacher preparation programs in Hawaii. Working toward solutions, project partners will include the UHM College of Education, STEM faculty from the College of Arts & Sciences and College of Engineering, as well as Kapiolani Community College (KCC) and the Hawaii State Department of Education.

These partners will work collaboratively to create pathways for undergraduates majoring across STEM fields (specifically, mathematics, science, and engineering) to pursue a double major with secondary education. In consultation with an expert on the effective UTeach model, the project partners will (1) design course sequences allowing STEM and education double majors; (2) design new courses to introduce teaching to students early in their college careers thus enabling them to concurrently complete STEM degrees and College of Education coursework; and (3) develop recruitment plans involving awareness-raising, advising, scholarships, and articulation agreements with UH system community colleges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The state of Hawai‘i is experiencing a major secondary STEM teacher shortage and is in dire need of teachers licensed in secondary STEM content areas. The College of Education (CoE) at the University of Hawai‘i Mānoa (UHM) has worked collaboratively with the UHM College of Natural Science, the UH Hilo Physics and Math Departments and the University of Colorado at Boulder (UC Boulder) Learning Assistance (LA) program to create pathways for undergraduates majoring across STEM fields (i.e., mathematics, science, and engineering) to generate awareness of and interest in pursuing careers in secondary education. The long-term goal of this cross-college initiative is to increase the number of licensed, highly effective secondary STEM educators in the state of Hawai‘i.

 

The goal of our Noyce capacity grant was to leverag underutilized infrastructure to begin addressing obstacles undergraduate students who major in STEM fields at UHM and UH Hilo encounter when exploring secondary STEM instruction as a career path, including:

  • 1) Current undergraduate education degree pathways require students to drop their STEM major in order to switch to an education major. This discourages students who are passionate about their STEM field from pursuing and becoming secondary teachers. 

  • 2) Those who do pursue an education major receive more limited STEM content preparation than those who major in STEM fields.

  • 3) STEM faculty are generally unaware of pathways for students interested in careers in secondary education and funding to support students in engaging in such pathways.

  • 4) Lack of coordination between STEM departments and CoE regarding student recruitment, advising and 4-year planning for students.

Over two years of grant implementation we have address the four (4) obstacles identified above in three (3) ways. First (1), via a partnership between UH CoE, UH College of Natural Science and the UC Boulder LA Program, we have developed teacher recruitment strategies that have resulted in UHM and UH Hilo STEM majors being more aware of opportunities in secondary STEM instruction. These recruitment strategist included CoE offering teacher information sessions in partnership with advisors and instructors in the College of Natural Sciences and piloting a STEM Pedagogy course to all first time Learning Assistants (LA) at UH Manoa and UH Hilo in Spring 2018, Fall 2018 and Spring 2019. As a result of participation in the LA STEM Pedagogy Course, there was a 13% increase in undergraduate STEM majors indicating an interest in exploring pathways to becoming a secondary STEM teacher upon completion of their undergraduate degree. Second (2), a new three credit undergraduate level course titled EDCS 417 STEM Pedagogy was approved by the UHM Chancellor's Office in Spring 2019 and will be offered every semester (Fall, Spring and Summer) starting Spring 2020 to students in STEM majors at UHM. The course provides an introduction to teaching science, math and STEM. Credits from this course can be used towards required elective credits in a STEM major and/or a minor in education. Third (3), we have established meaningful relationships, across the UHM system, that will serve as the foundation for the development of future pathways for undergraduates majoring in STEM fields to pursue careers in secondary STEM education. Most notably, PI O’Neill is currently working with the College of Natural Sciences at UHM and faculty in the Department of Physics at UH Hilo to author a Noyce Track II grant proposal to be submitted August 27, 2019. During the implementation of our current Noyce capacity grant we learned that undergraduate STEM majors at UHM found it prohibitivly overwhelming to complete the course work required for double majoring in a STEM field and Secondary Education in four years. Those interested in pathways to earning secondary teaching licensure indicated that they would prefer to complete their STEM undergraduate degree in four (4) years and participate in 5th year Masters of Education program. The Noyce Track II grant proposal to be submitted August 27, 2019 presents a pathway for a 4+1 design which will result in successful candidates earning an undergraduate degree in a STEM field, a Masters in Curriculum and Instruction and recommendation for Secondary Math, Science or STEM teaching licensure in the State of Hawai‘i in five (5) years.
